messageBody:
> A quick question: how do you have test dependency (in your sense) without
test content dependency?

No side effects, that was my differentiation. A test doesn't depend upon the
side effects of a run of another, but (at some user determined level) the
run of one test ought depend upon the completion of and success of another.

> When I wrote a few examples, I found that when one test depends on another
(in your sense) there is
> duplication in the tests. At a minimum, the two tests make the same
assertions.

Ok, another example. I have a class that walks a classpath and generates
listener events on things found, I test that. I have a class that listens to
such events to "find" things that match a certain criterion, I test that. If
the first class fails to send events, then I ought not blame (or dig into)
the second for not finding anything. The tests are (I believe) unit tests of
each, without duplication.

> The closer an object is to the core of your application, the more
important (I think) that failures in that > object yell loudly and
annoyingly.

If one is goign to test, then any single test failing is loud enough. Why
get 50 random reports when one focused one would do?

> If your project has a big problem with core classes failing on a regular
> basis, then maybe you have a process/people problem, as opposed to a
technical problem.

So junit is for folks who don't really need good testing? ;-)

regards

Adam
